pullrequest.title: Start of command line tool for parsing log files.

content.raw:
I just made a log of 20 seconds worth of `gazebo -r sdf/worlds/joint_damping_demo.world`. The compressed log is about 12 MB. I can step through the log just fine, and I can echo it to a file in about 10 seconds. Using the gzlog info command, however, takes about 30 seconds.

I noticed that the log stores incremental time changes for each state. Would it make sense to store the absolute times as well? This way you could just read the last chunk in the file to see the duration.
content.html:
I just made a log of 20 seconds worth of gazebo -r sdf/worlds/joint_damping_demo.world. The compressed log is about 12 MB. I can step through the log just fine, and I can echo it to a file in about 10 seconds. Using the gzlog info command, however, takes about 30 seconds.

I noticed that the log stores incremental time changes for each state. Would it make sense to store the absolute times as well? This way you could just read the last chunk in the file to see the duration.
